title: IndusInd Bank records profit growth, lower inflation in UK, & more

news.title: Quarterly Results: IndusInd Bank
news.description:
Reported a 69% year-on-year rise in net profit to Rs 1,959 cr.













Net interest income (revenue) rose 19% to Rs 4,495 cr.
Gross non-performing assets (% loans that are not being repaid) was down to 2.06% from 2.48% a year ago.

news.title: Word of the Day
news.description:
Capex
Capital Expenditure (Capex) is the money spent on buying or building fixed assets.
Example: factories, machinery, or other heavy equipment.
Since these involve a large outlay of money in one go, capex forms a large part of expenses for many companies.

news.title: 6 Day Course
news.description:
Theme: terms used to describe market downs
Day 3: Wednesday
Recession.
A recession occurs when the economic activity falls for 2 quarters or 6 months.
Do note, the terms we’ve discussed so far are applicable to individuals stocks as well as markets.
But recession is used to describe only the economic activity as a whole. Usually, if the GDP of a country falls for 2 quarters, the country is said to be in a recession.
A recession can last relatively longer — anywhere from 6 months to a few years.
A recession is also said to be temporary in nature — recovery from a recession is expected.
This definition is not fixed.
Recently, the USA’s economy contracted for 2 quarters but the US government did not call it a recession citing other positive economic indicators.
Some agreed with them. Some criticised them for not declaring a recession.

news.title: Featured Question
news.description:
"When prices of shares follow the usual demand and supply rule and vary accordingly, why is the company's performance even relevant? Theoretically, even if a company is performing poorly but people are buying its shares then the price should always go up. So shouldn't people buying/trading the stocks keep the share price at par? Why do people consider the performance of companies?"
 
If a company makes good profits, you get more profits — in the form of dividend (or share buybacks).
So, when a company’s profits go up, it becomes more attractive to investors. They’re willing to pay a higher price for the stock.
If more people are willing to pay a higher price for a stock, the stock price rises.
In short, the price is linked to the demand and supply for a stock — but the demand and supply for a stock is linked to the company’s performance (income, revenue, etc).
It must be noted here, not all companies give dividends or do buybacks. These companies are reinvesting their earnings back into the business to grow it further.
Even these companies are expected to give dividends or do share buybacks at some point in the future when they’re done aggressively growing.
